programme.title: Late Night Mix!

programme.desc: The documentary follows 12-year-old English traveller Royston, who spends most of his spare time in the gym training. His first fight was with a bully at school and now he has several titles and is on course to turn professional. But he is not the only one. Twins Johnny and Abraham have also had trouble with bullies and have resorted to fighting back, so before they get into trouble at school, their uncle - a professional cage fighter - is taking them under his wing in a training session. Meanwhile, 10-year-old Annie recently moved from the site where she was born into a house with her mother, but she is missing her friends

programme.desc: Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers perform a 2014 concert at Boston's Fenway Park

programme.title: Jeff Lynne's ELO at Hyde Park
programme.desc: On a sunny day in September 2014, Jeff Lynne, head honcho of 70s hit-making band ELO, took to the stage in London's Hyde Park and, with the help of his backing band and the strings of the BBC Concert Orchestra, brought to a close Radio 2's Live in Hyde Park annual festival. After an absence from the live stage for 28 years, this headline set by Jeff Lynne's ELO was a much-anticipated and talked-about event. In front of 50,000 people, Jeff Lynne delivered a rousing and crowd-pleasing string of the Electric Light Orchestra's chart-topping hits including, Livin' Thing, Sweet Talkin' Woman, Don't Bring Me Down, Mr Blue Sky, and Roll Over Beethoven. And there was also Jeff's touching tribute to his band buddies from Traveling Wilburys, in his performance of their 1988 hit Handle With Care

programme.title: David Bowie: Five Years
programme.desc: An intimate portrait of five key years in David Bowie's career. Featuring a wealth of previously unseen archive this film looks at how Bowie continually evolved, from Ziggy Stardust, to the Soul Star of Young Americans, to the 'Thin White Duke'. It explores his regeneration in Berlin with the critically acclaimed album Heroes, his triumph with Scary Monsters and his global success with Let's Dance. With interviews with all his closest collaborators, this film investigates how Bowie has become an 'icon of our times'

programme.title: Know Your Winter Trends: ALBERTA FERRETI

programme.title: Through the Night
programme.desc: With John Shea. Stravinsky: Octet. Beethoven: Piano Concerto No 2 in B flat, Op 19; Piano Concerto No 5 in E flat, Op 73 (Emperor); Piano Sonata No 18 in E flat, Op 31 No 3; 12 German Dances, Wo013. Leif Ove Andsnes (piano), Mahler Chamber Orchestra. 2.03 Lindblad: String Quartet No 6 in E flat. 2.31 CPE Bach: Magnificat in D, Wq215. 3.07 Brahms: Quartet No 3 in C minor for piano and strings, Op 60 (Werther). 3.43 Nielsen: Overture: Maskarade, FS39. 3.48 Turina: Homenaje a Navarra. 3.55 Gimenez: La Boda de Luis Alonso. 4.01 Fesch: Concerto in G minor for two flutes and orchestra, Op 5 No 2. 4.11 Sibelius: Five Esquisses for piano, Op 114. 4.20 Sarasate: Zigeunerweisen for violin and orchestra, Op 20. 4.31 Svendsen: Festival Polonaise, Op 12. 4.40 Norman: Rosa rorans bonitatem, Op 45. 4.49 Faure: Nocturne in C sharp minor, Op 74. 4.57 Warlock: Serenade for string orchestra (to Frederick Delius on his 60th Birthday). 5.04 Attrib Mozart: Adagio/Allegro in E flat for wind octet. 5.14 Barriere: Sonata No 10 in G for two cellos. 5.24 Faure: Pavane for orchestra, Op 50. 5.31 Fusz: Quartet for flute, viola, cello and guitar. 5.57 JM Bach: Liebster Jesu, hor mein Flehen - dialogue for five voices, two violins, two violas and basso continuo. 6.04 Sowande: African Suite for Strings

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Clemency Burton-Hill presents Radio 3's classical breakfast show, featuring listener requests. Including 7.00, 8.00 News. 7.30, 8.30 News Headlines

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.sub-title: Thursday - Rob Cowan and Angela Rippon
programme.desc: With Rob Walker. 9.00 Rob sets the tone and mood of the day's programme with a range of music to intrigue, surprise and entertain. 9.30 Musical challenge to identify a mystery musical personality. 10.00 Rob's guest is writer and presenter Angela Rippon, who talks about her career and chooses her favourite classical pieces. 10.30 Music in Time: Modern. Rob focuses on the modern era and a chamber-music masterpiece Schoenberg wrote during his convalescence from a near-fatal heart attack. Followed by Double Take. Rob explores the differences in style between recordings of an orchestral piece by Stravinsky. 11.00 Artists of the Week: Borodin Quartet. One of the great chamber ensembles of the last century, the Borodins were founded in 1945 and are still going strong today. Stylistically distinctive, their performances are always at the service of the music. Across the week Rob features them in string quartets by Beethoven, Borodin and Shostakovich, whose work they have always championed; in Brahms's Second Piano Quartet (with Sviatoslav Richter); and in Schnittke's Piano Quintet (with Ludmilla Berlinsky). Brahms: Piano Quartet No 2 in A, Op 26

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Ravel
programme.desc: Donald Macleod explores how Ravel - just over five feet tall, and long deemed unfit for the army - came to serve his nation during the First World War. Ravel: Bolero [1984 arrangement for Torvill and Dean].Trois beaux oiseaux du paradis (Trois Chansons). Accentus, conductor Laurence Equilbey. Fugue; Toccata (Le Tombeau de Couperin). Bertrand Chamayou (piano). La Valse. Montreal Symphony Orchestra, conductor Charles Dutoit. Tzigane [original version for violin and lutheal piano]. Daniel Hope (violin), Sebastian Knauer. (lutheal piano). Trois Chansons madecasses. Nora Gubisch (mezzo), Magali Mosnier (flute), Jerome Pernoo (cello), Alain Altinoglu (piano)

programme.title: News

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.sub-title: Malcolm Martineau: A Life in Song
programme.desc: Accompanist Malcolm Martineau continues the series in which he celebrate a life in music. Today he is joined by the celebrated German soprano Anne Schwanewilms to perform songs by Strauss and Wolf. Strauss: Traum durch die Dammerung Op 29 No 1; Nachtgang Op 29 No 3; Du meines Herzens Kronelein Op 21 No 2; Ach Lieb, ich muss nun scheiden Op 21 No 3. Wolf: Das verlassene Magdlein; Wo find ich Trost; Der Genesene an die Hoffnung. Strauss: In goldener Falle Op 49 No 2; Wiegenliedchen Op 49 No 3; Wer lieben will, muss leiden Op 49 No 7; Ach was Kummer, Qual und Schmerzen Op 49 No 8; Blauer Sommer Op 31 No 1; Weisser Jasmin Op 31 No 3; Das Rosenband Op 36 No 1; Drei Lieder der Ophelia (Wie erkenn ich mein Treulieb vor andern nun, Op 67 No 1. Guten Morgen, s'ist Sankt Valentintag, Op 67 No 2. Sie trugen ihn auf der Bahre bloss, Op 67 No 3). Malcolm Martineau (piano), Anne Schwanewilms (soprano)

programme.title: Afternoon on 3
programme.desc: Penny Gore introduces Massenet's comic opera Don Quichotte from Chicago Lyric opera, conducted by Andrew Davis. Premiered in 1910, it was Massenet's final operatic triumph, and his own situation echoed the fictional relationship between the aged Don Quichotte and the young beautiful Dulcinee. Massenet was infatuated with a singer half his age who sang the role of Dulcinee at the first performance, and Massenet can see the ridiculousness of the situation, but writes tenderly for the pair. Of course there is the Don's faithful servant Sancho Panza and windmills too, and bandits and a stolen jewel that Don Quichotte vows to return to Dulcinee - he thinks in return for becoming his wife. Towards the end of the opera Dulcinee quietly and sensitively thanks Don Quichotte for returning her jewel, but gives him a reality check - their destinies are completely different: she is in the present and looking to the future, he is a relic of the past - they can never be married. Feodor Chaliapin was the original Don Quichotte, and Ferrucio Furlanetto takes the central role in this performance. 2.00 Massenet : Don Quichotte. Clementine Margaine (mezzo: La belle Dulcinee), Ferruccio Furlanetto (bass: Don Quichotte), Nicola Alaimo (baritone: Sancho), Diana Newman (soprano: Pedro), Lindsay Metzger (soprano: Garcias), Jonathan Johnson (tenor: Rodriguez), Alec Carlson (tenor: Juan), Bradley Smoak (bass baritone: Tenebrun the Bandit Chief), Takaoki Onishi (baritone: First Servant), Emmett O'Hanlon (baritone: Second Servant), William Combs, Matthew Carroll, John Concepcion, Ronald Watkins (Four Bandits), Lyric Opera Orchestra and Chorus, Andrew Davis 3.55 Arnold: Clarinet Concerto. Michael Collins (soloist/director), BBC Symphony Orchestra

programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.sub-title: Hull: A Trip Down Memory Lane
programme.desc: Matthew Sweet visits Hull, the city where he grew up, seeking out the music of local movie composer Basil Kirchin, playwright Richard Bean's comedy The Hypocrite, about the city's part in the English Civil War, and the re-opened Ferens Art Gallery

programme.title: The Essay: Being Orson
programme.desc: Sarah Churchwell presents another in the series of essays by enthusiasts charting the rise and fall of Orson Welles, focuses on his talent for self-mythologising and how he compares with fiction's great fake, Jay Gatsby

programme.title: Late Junction
programme.sub-title: Nick Luscombe with a Basil Kirchin Tribute
programme.desc: Nick Luscombe pays tribute to avant-garde composer Basil Kirchin by showcasing some of his works and selected gems from his catalogue. Born in 1927, Kirchin was an elusive and enigmatic pioneer of British music. Originally a drummer inspired by jazz and mambo, his extraordinary musical journey included swing, rock 'n' roll, film scores and pop songwriting, before he retreated to Hull, where he created experimental sonic landscapes that still challenge convention, until his death in 2005

programme.title: Through the Night
programme.desc: John Shea presents a programme of Mozart chamber music from the 2016 RheinVokal Festival. programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.sub-title: Rob Cowan with Guest Angela Rippon
programme.desc: With Rob Cowan. 9.00 Rob introduces a range of music to intrigue, surprise and entertain. 9.30 The daily musical challenge sees listeners tasked to identify a piece of music played in reverse. 10.00 Rob is joined by the newsreader, broadcaster and writer Angela Rippon, who selects more of her favourite works. 10.30 Music in Time: Classical. Rob looks at the Classical period and Beethoven's first major set of variations - a form he would return to throughout his life. 11.00 Rob's Artists of the Week are the Borodin Quartet, without question one of the great chamber ensembles of the last century. Founded in 1945, the Borodins are stylistically distinctive, yet their performances are always at the service of the music. Shostakovich: String Quartet No.8 in C minor, Op 110. Borodin Quartet

programme.title: Afternoon on 3
programme.sub-title: BBC Symphony Orchestra and BBC Singers. With Penny Gore.
programme.desc: Penny Gore introduces music from the BBC Symphony Orchestra, including a track from its Grammy-nominated CD of Vaughan Williams orchestrations. A Road All Paved with Stars, by Vaughan Williams and arranged by Adrian Williams, is taken from his opera The Poisoned Kiss. Martyn Brabbins conducts the BBC Symphony Orchestra. There is another work by Richard Rodney Bennett from the BBC Symphony Orchestra's recent Total Immersion day at the Barbican Centre in London, and ahead of his performance with the BBC SO of Sibelius's complete Lemminkainen Suite at the Barbican on March 3, Sakari Oramo conducts the orchestra in Lemminkainen and theMaidens of Sari. Plus, the BBC Singers perform the world premiere performance of a modern Requiem setting by Philip Moore. 2.00 Richard Rodney Bennett: Anniversaries. BBC Symphony Orchestra, conductor Rumon Gamba. 2.20 Philip Moore: Requiem (world premiere). Stephen Farr (organ), BBC Singers, conductor David Hill. 3.20 Sibelius: Lemminkainen and the Maidens of Sari. BBC Symphony Orchestra, conductor Sakari Oramo. Philip Moore: Three Prayers of Dietrich Bonhoeffer. BBC Singers, conductor David Hill. 4.00 Vaughan Williams arr Adrian Williams: A Road All Paved with Stars - A Symphonic Rhapsody from The Poisoned Kiss. BBC Symphony Orchestra, conductor Martyn Brabbins

programme.title: Radio 3 in Concert
programme.sub-title: BBC SO with Jonas Kaufmann in Strauss's Four Last Songs
programme.desc: At London's Barbican Hall, Jonas Kaufmann sings Richard Strauss's Four Last Songs with the BBC Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Jochen Rieder. Plus, works by Strauss, Elgar's In the South and Korngold's Schauspiel Overture. Presented by Martin Handley. Jonas Kaufmann (tenor), BBC Symphony Orchestra, conductor Jochen Rieder. Korngold: Schauspiel Ouverture, Op 4. Richard Strauss: Four Symphonic Interludes (Intermezzo, Op 72a); Songs. Interval. Elgar: In the South (Alassio). Richard Strauss: Four Last Songs. Strauss's Four Last Songs are the ultimate romantic orchestral songs - and the final, gorgeous sunset of German Romanticism. The last concert of the great German tenor Jonas Kaufmann's Barbican Residency finds him breaking new ground in this most rapturous of musical farewells. True, they're more usually sung by a soprano, but the prospect of hearing Kaufmann's transcendent tone and unparalleled sensitivity in Strauss's final masterpiece is mouth-watering. There'll be other Strauss songs too. And regular collaborator Jochen Rieder conducts the BBC Symphony Orchestra in Elgar's exuberant concert overture In the South - subtitled Alassio after the town on the Italian Riviera where Elgar and his wife were staying in 1904 - and which Elgar claimed he 'wove in the valley of Andora during a long and lovely day al fresco', and Korngold's Schauspiel Overture, the extraordinary creation of a very gifted fourteen-year old. Recorded on Monday 13th February

programme.title: The Verb
programme.desc: Ian McMillan is joined by much-respected poet and novelist Helen Dunmore. Helen won the inaugural Orange Prize for fiction for A Spell of Winter, the National Poetry Competition for her poem The Malarkey, and has been acclaimed for her children's books and short stories. Ian explores the themes that animate Helen's work, the way the sea continues to tug at her imagination, her writing process particularly in relation to her new novel Birdcage Walk, and her latest collection of poetry, Inside the Wave

programme.title: The Essay: Being Orson
programme.desc: In the last in a series of essays by enthusiasts following Orson Welles' rise and fall, film critic David Thomson explores the actor-director's complicated relationship with failure, looking at a career littered with lost and half-finished projects

programme.desc: Matthew Sweet introduces music from films featuring a connection to the Moon, in the week that marks the release of Hidden Figures, which tells the story of the African-American women who worked as mathematicians behind the scenes at NASA in the 1960s. The film itself features a score by Hans Zimmer, Pharrell Williams and Benjamin Wallfisch

programme.desc: Julian Joseph presents a solo performance by singer and pianist Ian Shaw, recorded at the 2016 Gateshead Jazz Festival. Shaw's repertoire features music by Leonard Cohen and Joni Mitchell, and a version of David Bowie's Life On Mars. The performer also speaks about working and touring with Bowie, and the humanitarian work he is currently involved in at the `Jungle' migrant encampment in Calais

programme.title: Opera on 3: Live from the Met
programme.desc: Mary Jo Heath and Ira Siff introduce a performance of Bellini's I Puritani, broadcast live from the Met in New York. In Engliand, during the Civil War, a Puritan stronghold is under threat from Royalist troops. Within the fortress, Elvira, daughter of the commander has been promised to Riccardo, but is in love with Arturo, a Royalist. When she mistakenly believes herself betrayed by Arturo, it's enough to drive her mad. Diana Damrau sings Elvira, with Javier Camarena and Alexey Markov as the two men in her life. Javier Camarena (tenor: Lord Arturo Talbot), Diana Damrau (soprano: Elvira Walton), Alexey Markov (baritone: Sir Riccardo Forth), Luca Pisaroni (bass: Sir Giorgio Walton), David Crawford (bass: Lord Gualtiero Walton), Eduardo Valdes (tenor: Sir Bruno Robertson), Virginie Verrez (mezzo-soprano: Enrichetta di Francia), New York Metropolitan Opera Chorus, New York Metropolitan Opera Orchestra, conductor Maurizio Benini

programme.title: Hear and Now
programme.desc: Tom McKinney presents a rich mix of new music recorded in concert. From a Kammer Klang concert earlier this month at London's Cafe Oto, there are two world premieres: Cassandra Miller: Tracery, Hardanger, Juliet Fraser (soprano). Cassandra Miller: Traveller Song, Ensemble Plus-Minus. Also new music by Lisa Illean, and a solo by sound artist Christine Sun Kim. Modern Muses, our occasional series of composers and favourite collaborators, tonight features composer Josephine Stephenson and violinist Fiona Monbet comparing notes on their work together. And from last November's Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival, a virtuosic violin solo, Haare by Enno Poppe; and a major ensemble piece by Marcin Stanczyk, Some Drops, featuring Marco Blaauw (trumpet) with Ensemble Musikfabrik

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.sub-title: Wigmore Hall Mondays: Kathryn Rudge & James Baillieu
programme.desc: Mezzo-soprano Kathryn Rudge and pianist James Baillieu perform a recital of English song from Wigmore Hall in London. English song flourished at the beginning of the 20th century and was influenced by the wealth of poetry and the trauma of global warfare. Today's concert journeys through a programme of songs by Howells and Quilter and a rarity by Denis Browne, and Kathryn and James are joined by viola player Gary Pomeroy for three songs by Frank Bridge. Presented by Clemency Burton-Hill. Herbert Howells: Come sing and dance. Roger Quilter: Go, lovely rose; Now sleeps the crimson petal; Music, when soft voices die. William Charles Denis Browne: To Gratiana, dancing and singing. Herbert Howells: Peacock Pie - song-cycle Op.33. Ivor Gurney: Sleep; Most holy night; The Fields are full; By a bierside. Frank Bridge: Far, far from each other; Where is it that our soul doth go?; Music when soft voices die. Kathryn Rudge (mezzo-soprano), James Baillieu, (piano), Gary Pomeroy (viola)

programme.title: The Early Music Show
programme.desc: Director of The Dufay Collective, William Lyons, celebrates the life and work of one of his musical heroes - early music specialist, historian, multi-instrumentalist, broadcaster and pioneer David Munrow, who took his own life in 1976 during a state of depression at the age of just 33. Munrow perhaps did more than anyone else in the second half of the 20th century to popularise early music in Great Britain, despite a career lasting barely ten years. This was underscored when the Voyager space probe committee selected one of his recordings to be carried on it as part of the Voyager Golden Record. He left behind him not only his recordings but a large collection of musical instruments. The Munrow Archive at the Royal Academy of Music holds a collection of his letters, papers, TV scripts, scores, musical compositions and books which is accessible to the public

programme.title: Choral Evensong
programme.desc: From the Chapel of the Queen's College, Oxford. Introit: Behold, O God Our Defender (John Scott). Response: Humphrey Clucas. Hymn: The Duteous Day Now Closeth (Innsbruck). Organ Voluntary: Sonata No 5 - Finale (Francis Jackson). Director of Music: Owen Rees. Assistant Organist: David Bednall

programme.title: The Choir
programme.desc: Sara Mohr-Pietsch introduces this week's pick of the choral world. Wine expert, author and occasional professional chorister, Oz Clarke chats with Sara about some of his favourite choral music. Another amateur choir introduce themselves in 'Meet My Choir'

programme.title: The Listening Service
programme.sub-title: In Space No-One Can Hear You Sing....
programme.desc: Space. A place few men or women has gone before, but plenty of composers have. The universe has inspired musicians for hundreds of years and consequently we all know what space music sounds like. Or do we? From Holst and David Bowie to John Williams via Bjork and Stockhausen, Tom Service dons his spacesuit on a mission to explore why space inspired music sounds the way it does. He's joined by space scientist Lucie Green to discover what the reality of sound in space is, while mathematician Elaine Chew helps him uncover the music of the spheres

programme.title: Words and Music
programme.desc: Poetry, music and readings reflecting on the nautical life, including words by Masefield, Melville, Homer and Hardy, and music by Britten, Mendelssohn, Purcell and Tom Waits. Read by Lesley Sharp and John Shrapnel

programme.title: Sunday Feature: King Kong - the Township Jazz Musical
programme.desc: The award-winning alto saxophonist Soweto Kinch uncovers the story of King Kong, an extraordinary musical collaboration that took place in apartheid-torn South Africa inspired by the life and tragic death of the heavyweight-boxing champion Ezekiel Dlamini. The show defied the colour bar and lead the way as part of a cultural renaissance; it became Nelson Mandela's favourite musical and proved, beyond doubt, that co-operation and respect make indomitable bedfellows. Its creators consciously intended it to be a model of fruitful co-operation between black and white South Africans in the international entertainment field, and a direct challenge to apartheid. Starring Miriam Makeba, King Kong toured South Africa for two years playing to over a quarter of a million people, two thirds of whom were white. It then arrived in London's West End in 1961. Singer Abigail Kubeka talks about the infamous township of Sophiatown and her memories of Ezekiel, whilst Hugh Masekela recalls the show and its composer Todd Matshikisa. We meet Irene Menel, anti-apartheid activist and philanthropist who, with her husband Clive, put the show together against all the odds. Lyricist Pat Williams talks about the difficulties of writing under the shadow of apartheid. A revival of King Kong is scheduled for 2017; Eric Abraham, its producer, comments on its timelessness and relevance in today's South Africa

Perfido!, Op 65. Mendelssohn: Infelice, Op 94. Christiane Karg, soprano; Bamberg Symphony Orchestra; David Afkham. Recorded at the Mecklenburg-Vorpommern Festival on July 17 2016. Maxim Rysanov, viola; Tae-Hyung Kim, piano. Beethoven: Piano Trio No 5 in D, Pp 70/1 ('Ghost'). Boris Brovtsyn, violin; Myung-Wha Chung, cello; Norman Krieger, piano. programme.title: Drama on 3: The Process
programme.desc: A new adaptation of Franz Kafka's classic book The Trial, dramatised and updated by Mark Ravenhill as part of Radio 3's series In the Shadow of Kafka. A man is arrested and prosecuted by a remote, inaccessible authority, but the nature of his crime is not revealed to him. Sam Troughton (Joseph Kay), Caroline Catz (Caroline/Emma), Joe Armstrong (Frank/Terry/John, an actor), Lloyd Hutchinson (Will), Pearce Quigley (Martin), Hara Yannas (Abi/Katy, an actor), Lloyd Hutchinson (Jason/Bartle), Tony Gardner (The Facilitator/Block), Jo Joyner (Anne/Zoe), Sinead Matthews (Leni), Marion Bailey (Huld), Gaye Brown (O'Reilly), Harle Jordean (Child). programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Clemency Burton-Hill presents Radio 3's classical breakfast show, featuring listener requests. Including 7.00, 8.00 News. 7.30, 8.30 News Headlines

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: With Sarah Walker. 9.00 Sarah sets the tone and mood of the day's programme with a range of music to intrigue, surprise and entertain. 9.30 Today's musical challenge is listen to the clues and identify a musical mystery object. 10.00 The guest this week is artist Maggi Hambling , who has made her mark in a number of fields, including painting, portraiture and sculpture. Her best-known piece is Scallop, which stands on Aldeburgh beach in Suffolk and is dedicated to Benjamin Britten - the town's most celebrated son. As well as discussing her life and work, Maggi shares some of her favourite classical music, including Purcell, Britten and the synaesthetic composer Deborah Pritchard. 10.30 Music in Time. Sarah heads back to the Romantic period and a late piano sonata by Beethoven that shows how he pushed the boundaries of both form and the piano itself. 11.00 Artist of the Week. This week Sarah explores some of the London Sinfonietta's finest recordings with music by composers including Gorecki, Stravinsky, Takemitsu, Harrison Birtwistle and John Tavener. Stravinsky: Histoire du Soldat. London Sinfonietta, conductor Riccardo Chailly

programme.title: Composer of the Week: Gade
programme.desc: Donald Macleod charts Danish composer Niels Gade's life and career, beginning by looking at the period leading up to his breakthrough in the musical world. Born in 1817, Gade's childhood was marked by the economic hardship endured in Copenhagen after Denmark declared bankruptcy in 1813. Despite the disadvantages of a lack of money and a limited access to education, aged 23, Gade won a prestigious competition with an astonishingly accomplished orchestral overture Echoes of Ossian. programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: Sarah Walker presents. 9.00 Sarah sets the tone and mood of the day's programme with a range of music to intrigue, surprise and entertain. 9.30 Take part in the daily musical challenge to identify a piece of music played backwards. 10.00 Sarah's guest this week is artist Maggi Hambling. In a career spanning nearly 50 years Maggi has made her mark in a number of fields, including painting, portraiture and sculpture. Her best-known piece is Scallop, which stands on Aldeburgh beach in Suffolk, and is dedicated to the town's most celebrated son, Benjamin Britten. 10.30 Music in Time: Medieval. Sarah heads back to the Medieval period to look at a musical device called a clausula, a way of taking existing plainchant melodies and developing them further. Double Take: Sarah explores the nature of performance by highlighting the differences in style between two interpretations of Debussy's Clair de lune, one for piano and the other for orchestra. 11.00 Artist of the Week: London Sinfonietta. Imbued with a mission to perform the best contemporary classical music, develop new work and nurture new talent, the London Sinfonietta are one of the most vibrant and exciting ensembles in the UK. Since their first concert in 1968 - the world premiere of John Tavener's The Whale - the Sinfonietta have commissioned more than 300 works and premiered hundreds more. Takemitsu: Quotation of Dream - Say sea, take me! Paul Crossley (piano) Peter Serkin (piano) London Sinfonietta , conductor Oliver Knussen

programme.title: Radio 3 Lunchtime Concert
programme.desc: The Schubertiade at the Monastery of Santa Maria de Vilabertran, Catalunya. This week Fiona Talkington presents music by Haydn, Schubert, Brahms and Shostakovich in performances recorded in the Romanesque church of Catalonia's best-preserved medieval monastery. The monastery traces its origins to 1069 and since 1997 its walls have echoed to the sound of chamber music as each year it hosts a prestigious music festival. Among the artists visiting in 2016 were the Casals Quartet, named after Catalonia's famous musical son, the brilliant pianist, Denis Kozhukhin and the rich soprano of Juliana Banse, one of the world's leading lieder singers. New to the festival was the fresh-voiced young soprano, Anna Lucia Richter who can be heard today in a collection of songs by Schubert. Haydn: Keyboard Sonata No 33 in D, Hob XVI:24. Denis Kozhukhin (piano). Schubert: Hoffnung, D 295 (Text: Friedrich von Schiller); Suleika, D 720 (Text: Marianne von Willemer). Schubert: 3 songs from Wilhelm Meister, D 877 (Texts by Goethe); Nur wer die Sehnsucht kennt; Heiss mich nicht reden; So lasst mich scheinen . Anna Lucia Richter (soprano), Michael Gees (piano). Haydn: String Quartet No 23 in F minor, Hob III:35 (Sun). Casals Quartet

programme.desc: BBC Singers and their chief conductor, David Hill, celebrate Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, with two choral works from either end of his short life. Recorded in Milton Court, London, the BBC Singers are joined by St James' Baroque and soloists Lauren Fagan, Catherine Hopper, Ben Johnson and David Stout. programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.sub-title: Shakespeare in Cartoons; Jess Phillips; Sidney Nolan's Australian Legends
programme.desc: Outspoken Labour MP Jess Phillips speaks about living her life in the public eye. Plus, a feature on how Ned Kelly and Lady Macbeth - one a historical figure, the other imagined - have been instrumental as ciphers to the human condition. Anne McElvoy talks to Rebecca Daniels, curator of an exhibition marking 100 years since the birth of Sidney Nolan, the modern artist who transformed Kelly into a legend, and to David Taylor, curator of an exhibition at the Royal Shakespeare about the way memorable images transform into legends

programme.title: Breakfast
programme.desc: Clemency Burton-Hill presents Radio 3's classical breakfast show, featuring listener requests. Including 7.00, 8.00 News. 7.30, 8.30 News Headlines

programme.title: Essential Classics
programme.desc: Sarah Walker presents. 9.00 Sarah sets the tone and mood of the day's programme with a range of music to intrigue, surprise and entertain. 10.00 Sarah's guest this week is the artist Maggi Hambling. In a career spanning nearly 50 years Maggi has made her mark in a number of fields, including painting, portraiture and sculpture. Her best-known piece is Scallop, which stands on Aldeburgh beach in Suffolk, and is dedicated to the town's most celebrated son, Benjamin Britten. Another of her sculptures, A Conversation with Oscar Wilde, was the first public monument dedicated to the playwright and novelist. As well as discussing her life and work, Maggi shares some of her favourite classical music, including Purcell, Britten and the synaesthetic composer Deborah Pritchard. 10.30 Music in Time: Modern. Sarah is in the Modern period exploring Bartok's collection of piano pieces, Mikrokosmos, a brilliant example of how 20th-century composers exploited the percussive capabilities of the instrument. 11.00 Artist of the Week: London Sinfonietta. Imbued with a mission to perform the best contemporary classical music, develop new work and nurture new talent, the London Sinfonietta are one of the most vibrant and exciting ensembles in the UK, and arguably the world. Tavener. The Whale. London Sinfonietta, conductor David Atherton

programme.title: Free Thinking
programme.desc: Matthew Sweet talks to writers Paul Kingsnorth and Elizabeth-Jane Burnett and scientist Jules Pretty about Soil and Culture and Survival Stories. For some Soil is where they come from, for others it is an object of aesthetic beauty, for most of us it is the means by which we get what we need to live. Poet and writer Elizabeth-Jane Burnett's forthcoming A Dictionary of Soil explores the lives lived within and through the soil of three fields which constitute the origins of her family's ancestral village. The novelist and essayist Paul Kingsnorth spent his youth as an Environmental activist but now believes that if the Anthropocene is not to be Man's last hurrah, he and his fellow writers and artists need to produce stories that will wake us up to changing the habits of thousands of years. Which is where agroecology expert, Jules Pretty comes in. He says Soil We Can Rebuild It and in an environmentally friendly way and it will continue to feed us. They join Matthew Sweet to think through our developing relationship with the life-giving dirt beneath our feet and discuss whether a happy ending just might be possible

programme.title: Ramblings
programme.sub-title: The Doolough Famine Walk, County Mayo
programme.desc: New series. Clare Balding travels to County Mayo, Ireland, to retrace the steps of those who walked from Louisburg to Delphi in 1849 at the height of the potato famine in the hope of receiving aid. Hundreds of people come from all over the world each year to walk the 12 miles - now known as the Doolough Tragedy Famine Walk - in memory of those who died of starvation along the route. Clare talks to Joe Murray, who organises the event, Mary O'Malley, whose forebears suffered during the Great Hunger - or An Gorta Mor - and by Professor John Maguire, who puts the famine into historical context

programme.title: Ramblings
programme.sub-title: The Doolough Famine Walk, County Mayo
programme.desc: Clare Balding travels to County Mayo, Ireland, to retrace the steps of those who walked from Louisburg to Delphi in 1849 at the height of the potato famine in the hope of receiving aid. Hundreds of people come from all over the world each year to walk the 12 miles - now known as the Doolough Tragedy Famine Walk - in memory of those who died of starvation along the route. Clare talks to Joe Murray, who organises the event, Mary O'Malley, whose forebears suffered during the Great Hunger - or An Gorta Mor - and by Professor John Maguire, who puts the famine into historical context

programme.title: And the Academy Award Goes To
programme.desc: New series. Paul Gambaccini returns with the show celebrating the history of the Academy Awards, via three more notable nominees. Inspired by the announcement that Damien Chazelle's La La Land is in with a chance of winning 14 Oscars this year, Paul turns attention to All About Eve; which in 1950 became the first film to achieve that many nominations. Eventually claiming six statuettes, All About Eve helped lead actress Bette Davis make her comeback, and became another chapter in the Academy's long and storied history of showering acclaim on films about show-business

programme.title: Smooth Classics at Seven
programme.desc: John Brunning presents soothing sounds, featuring something for everyone

programme.title: The Full Works Concert
programme.desc: It's 60 years to the day since Liverpool's Philharmonic Society and Orchestra became the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic. Tonight Catherine Bott presents two hours of some of the greatest recordings made by Classic FM's Orchestra in the North West of England. Vaughan Williams: English Folksongs Suite. Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor James Judd. Ravel: Bolero. Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor Libor Pesek. Einaudi: Divenire. Mari Samuelsen (violin), Hakon Samuelsen (cello), Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor Clark Rundell. Elgar: Symphony No.1 in A-flat Op 55. Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra, conductor Vasily Petrenko. Tchaikovsky: Variations on a Rococo Theme Op 33. programme.sub-title: Scarlatti, Scandanavia, and the Central Steppes

Scarlatti: Keyboard Sonata in E K.380. Joanna MacGregor (piano). Schubert: Symphony No.8 in B minor D.759. Philharmonia Orchestra, conductor Giuseppe Sinopoli
